fields.headline: A degree of thought
fields.bodyText: Yes, you're right, Jackie, what we do when we teach the humanities is read a book or two once at the beginning of our careers and then just teach the same books the same way for 40 years (A graduate tax won't happen. But tuition fees can be fairer, 11 October). It's the same book, because nothing like, say, feminism, ever happens to suggest that we should look at other books or look at them in different ways. We should just tell the students what's what, not brook any critical discussion, certainly not encourage them to think critically about the society they're in, and get them out the door as quickly as possible. Two years, easy! Now I think about it, why do you need a week to think up those columns? And do you really need half a page to get your point across? Professor Jon Mee University of Warwick • Julian Futter (Letters, 9 October) might be surprised to know it was the Swedish government that asked the Germans to stamp the letter J in red on German passports in the early 1940s to make it easier for Swedish immigration officials to prevent German Jews from entering Sweden. Sweden was very antisemitic between the first and second world wars and some Swedish newspapers, as early as 1927, published lists of Jewish shops and other Jewish-owned businesses, advising their readers to avoid them. Inger Collingridge Exeter • With regard to resisting increases in tuition fees to be charged by universities in England (Cable struggles to stem revolt on tuition fees, 13 October), has anyone else noticed Vince Cable's remarkable transformation in the past few months from Stalin to Mr Bean? David Hart Edinburgh • When I first joined the Export Credits Guarantee Department in the 1960s, my two bosses were Messrs Todd and Barber (Letters, 9 October). John Sweeney Machen, Caerphilly • It was good to see the Guardian taking nominative determinism so seriously that it asked Stuart Gander to comment on the North Korean goosestep (Shortcuts, G2, 12 October). David Gurney Nottingham
